title: Empirical distribution
text: demonstrate R package algebraic.dst, consider relatively simple case observed sample , assume, ..d. random variables \(X_1,\ldots,X_n\) unknown distribution \(F\). use R package algebraic.dist estimate distribution \(F\).
code: library(algebraic.dist) #>  #> Attaching package: 'algebraic.dist' #> The following object is masked from 'package:grDevices': #>  #>     pdf

title: Empirical distribution
text: define parameters ..d. random sample : observed sample size \(n=100\). show observations sample :

title: Exponential distribution
text: demonstrate R package algebraic.dst, consider relatively simple case exponentially distributed random variables. First, load R package algebraic.dist :

title: Exponential distribution
text: define parameters ..d. random sample : generate random sample \(X_i \sim \operatorname{EXP}(\lambda=0.5)\) \(=1,\ldots,n\) : observed sample size \(n=10^{4}\). show observations sample : Let’s retrieve functions: show histogram sample overlaid plot exponential function’s pdf, cdf, survival, :  construct data frame showing mean variance way three ways , using mean vcov, using expectation (defined dist objects using Monte Carlo integration), using analytical formulae mean variance exponential definitions , using sample mean sample variance. also provide way retrieving support distribution:
code: n <- 10000 rate <- .5 exp.dist <- exp_dist(rate=rate) sampler <- sampler(exp.dist) data <- sampler(n) head(data, n = 4) #> [1] 1.501851 2.003706 1.463567 2.636245 f <- pdf(exp.dist) F <- cdf(exp.dist) hist(data, freq = FALSE, breaks = 40, ylim = c(0, 1)) curve(f(x), add = TRUE, col = "red") curve(F(x), add = TRUE, col = "blue") expectation(exp.dist, function(x) x^2) #> $value #> [1] 8.120095 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 7.752313 8.487876 #>  #> $n #> [1] 10000 df <- data.frame(   analytical = c(mean(exp.dist),                  vcov(exp.dist)),   mc = c(expectation(exp.dist, function(x) x)$value,          expectation(exp.dist, function(x) (x - mean(exp.dist))^2)$value),   sample = c(mean(data), var(data)) ) row.names(df) <- c("mean", "variance") print(df) #>          analytical       mc   sample #> mean              2 1.987296 1.997524 #> variance          4 3.733742 3.910412 support <- sup(exp.dist) contains(support, 2) #> [1] TRUE infinum(support) #> [1] 0 supremum(support) #> [1] Inf

what:
Retrieve the variance-covariance matrix (or scalar)
of a mvn object.
A variance-covariance matrix is a square matrix
giving the covariance between each pair of elements
of a given random vector. Importantly, its diagonal
contains variances of the elements — vcov.mvn
title:
Retrieve the variance-covariance matrix (or scalar)
of a mvn object.
A variance-covariance matrix is a square matrix
giving the covariance between each pair of elements
of a given random vector. Importantly, its diagonal
contains variances of the elements — vcov.mvn
